case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Moon Mills Ltd., Bombay

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench A, referred a question to the High Court at Calcutta under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Sikri, J. The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench A, referred the following question under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, to the High Court at Calcutta

facts.text: The question referred was whether Rs. 19,81,899 received by the assessee in 1950, being surplus of compensation over written down value of assets destroyed by fire in 1948, is taxable under 4th proviso to section 10(2)(vii) as income for 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 19,81,899 received by the assessee in 1950, being the surplus of the companypensation money over the written down value of the assets destroyed by fire in the year 1948, is taxable under the 4th proviso to section 10 2  vii  as the income of the assessee for the year 1950 ?

facts.text: Relevant assessment year is 1951-52 and corresponding accounting year is calendar year 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The facts and circumstances out of which the question arose are as follows The relevant assessment year 1951-52 and the companyresponding accounting year is the calendar year 1950.

facts.text: Moon Mills Ltd., Bombay (assessee), carried on manufacture and sale of cotton yarn and cotton piece-goods in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The Moon Mills Ltd., Bombay, respondent, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, carried on the manufacture and sale of companyton yarn and companyton piece-goods in Bombay.

facts.text: On June 6, 1948, a fire broke out destroying the building and partially destroying and damaging machinery and plant.

anchor.surface_text: On June 6, 1948, a devastating fire broke out in the premises of the mills of the assessee destroying the building and partially destroying and damaging the machinery and plant.

facts.text: Compensation settled between insurers and assessee at Rs. 62,41,177.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of companypensation was settled between the insurers and the assessee at Rs. 62,41,177.

facts.text: Compensation amount received by assessee in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Although the settlement took place in 1948, the amount was received by the assessee in 1950.

facts.text: Manufacturing operations ceased after the fire, but other trading activities continued on restricted scale in 1948, 1949, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The manufacturing operations of the mills ceased after the fire, though the other trading activities were companytinued throughout the years 1948, 1949 and 1950, on a restricted scale.

facts.text: Fixed assets destroyed by fire were not used for business in 1950 but were used in 1948 before destruction.

anchor.surface_text: The fixed assets of the business in respect of which companypensation was claimed from the insurers having been destroyed and put out of order by the fire were number used for the purpose of business in the year 1950 in which the companypensation was received but they had been so used in the year 1948 before they were destroyed by fire.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 22,35,181 as profit assessable under fourth proviso to section 10(2)(vii) and included it in total income for AY 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer for the assessment year 1951-52 held that a sum of Rs. 22,35,181 was profit assessable under the fourth proviso the section 10 2   vii , and included this in the total income of the assessee.

facts.text: Assessee argued before Appellate Assistant Commissioner that fourth proviso not applicable as fixed assets not used for business during accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner it was argued by the assessee that the fourth proviso was number applicable to the case in view of the fact that the fixed assets for which companypensation was received were number used for the purposes of business during the accounting year.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected assessee's contention but reduced amount to Rs. 19,81,899.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected this companytention, but reduced the amount chargeable under the fourth proviso to Rs. 19,81,899.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal sustained order of Appellate Assistant Commissioner but on different considerations.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench A, sustained the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner but on different companysiderations.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative and in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax obtained special leave, appeal before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax having obtained special leave, the appeal is number before us.

facts.text: Revenue's counsel contended High Court erred in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the revenue companytended that the High Court erred in answering the question in favour of the assessee

facts.text: Assessee's counsel relied on three recent decisions of Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: while Mr. Desai, relying on three recent decision of this companyrt, urged that the point was almost companycluded in his favour.

facts.text: Supreme Court interpreted second proviso in CIT v. Express Newspapers Ltd. and CIT v. Ajax Products Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: This companyrt recently interpreted proviso 2 above in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Express Newspapers Ltd. and Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ajax Products Ltd.

facts.text: It is not disputed that none of the conditions for taxing under fourth proviso are satisfied on facts of case.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that on the facts of this case numbere of these companyditions are satisfied.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court answer correct.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from the above reasoning that the answer returned by the High Court is companyrect.

facts.text: Business continued in 1950 on restricted scale after fire.

anchor.surface_text: The manufacturing operations of the mills ceased after the fire, though the other trading activities were companytinued throughout the years 1948, 1949 and 1950, on a restricted scale.

facts.text: Fixed assets not used in business in year 1950 when compensation received.

anchor.surface_text: The fixed assets of the business in respect of which companypensation was claimed from the insurers having been destroyed and put out of order by the fire were number used for the purpose of business in the year 1950

facts.text: Compensation settlement took place in 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Although the settlement took place in 1948, the amount was received by the assessee in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that before the excess of insurance money received over the difference between the written down value and scrap value is brought to charge it is essential that  1  during the previous year in which moneys are received the business shall have been carried on by the assessee for the part or whole of it and  2  the machinery shall have been used in the business in that previous year.

holdings.text: The fourth proviso has to be interpreted as strictly as the second proviso.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these decisions the question arises whether the fourth proviso should be interpreted differently. It has to be interpreted as strictly as the second proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recent Supreme Court decisions on second proviso require strict interpretation of taxing provisions; unambiguous words given natural meaning fitting section scheme.

holdings.text: Before excess insurance money is brought to charge under fourth proviso, essential that (1) business carried on during previous year of receipt for part or whole, and (2) building/machinery/plant used in business in that previous year.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that before the excess of insurance money received over the difference between the written down value and scrap value is brought to charge it is essential that  1  during the previous year in which moneys are received the business shall have been carried on by the assessee for the part or whole of it and  2  the machinery shall have been used in the business in that previous year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to conditions for second proviso in Express Newspapers Ltd. and Ajax Products Ltd.; 'such' assets refer to those used in business; charges escaped profits only if conditions met; strict construction.

holdings.text: None of the conditions for taxing under the fourth proviso are satisfied on the facts of the case.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that on the facts of this case none of these conditions are satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fixed assets destroyed in 1948, not used in business in 1950 when compensation received; no dispute on facts.

holdings.text: The surplus of Rs. 19,81,899 received in 1950 is not taxable under the 4th proviso to section 10(2)(vii) as income for 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from the above reasoning that the answer returned by the High Court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditions of fourth proviso not satisfied on facts; High Court correctly answered question in negative.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Express Newspapers Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Express Newspapers Ltd.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Express Newspapers Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Conditions to bring sale proceeds to charge under second proviso to section 10(2)(vii): business carried on in previous year, machinery used in business, sold when business carried on and not for winding up.
precedents.cited_holding: Therefore, to bring the sale proceeds to charge, the following conditions shall be fulfilled 1 during the entire previous year or a part of it the business shall have been carried on by the assessee 2 the machinery shall have been used in the business and 3 the machinery shall have been sold when the business was being carried on and number for the purpose of closing it down or winding it up.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ajax Products Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ajax Products Ltd.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ajax Products Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Strict construction of second proviso to section 10(2)(vii); natural meaning of words like 'such building', applicable whether during continuance or after cessation of business.
precedents.cited_holding: To put it in other words, the subject is number to be taxed unless the charging provision clearly imposes the obligation. Equally important is the rule of companystruction that if the words of a statute are precise and unambiguous, they must be accepted as declaring the express intentions of the legislature. Giving a close scrutiny to the second proviso, it will be clear that by giving the natural meaning to very word used therein, it clearly fits in within the scheme of the entire section. The key expressions in the proviso are 1 such building, 2 whether during the companytinuance of the business or after the cessation thereof and 3 deemed to be the profits of the previous year.
